ï»¿Execution Version 7 Dated October 9, 2014 COLLABORATION ARRANGEMENT relating to Global In rastructure Facility Partnership Program
ï»¿Execution Version This Collaboration Arrangement is er tered into on October 9, 2014 between: (1) DBS BANK LTD., representbd by its Chief Executive Officer and headquartered at 12 Me -i Boulevard, Level 3, Marina Eay Financial Center Tower 3, Singapore 018982 ("DBS"); an :I (2) THE WORLD BANK GROU 3, comprising the INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DIEVELOPMENT ("IBRD") and INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPI 11I T ASSOCIATION ("IDA"), headquartered at 1818 H Street, NW, Washington, DC 20433, U! the INTERNATIONAL FINANCE CORPORATION, ("IFC") headquartered at 2121 Pennsylva ,i: Avenue, NW, Washington, CC 20433, USA, and the MULTILATERAL INVESTMENT GUARANTEE AGENCY, ("MIlGA"), headquartered at 1818 H Street, NW, Washington, D : 2 433, USA (the "World Bank Group") (each a "Party" and together, the "Parties"). Preamble (A) There is broad international recognition, as confirmed by the G20, the OECD, Intein: )nal Organizations (IOs), the G7'., and the private sector represented by the B20 that investir c i! the infrastructure of Emerging Markets and Developing Economies (EMDEs) is needed, to (x and access to basic services an J raise living standards for all, and to meet global economit ;Ii wth targets. (B) Meeting this need present! a significant financing challenge. Given constraints on cx ting sources of infrastructure finnce-particularly in the public sector-a redoubled and coc *r ited effort is needed to mobilize F rivate sector finance for EMDE infrastructure. (C) There is an absence of robist pipelines of structurally sound and bankable projects an-1 t s is understood to be the greates t barrier to achieving significantly more infrastructure investrr - (D) Governments, development inance institutions, donors, and private investors share an in :E 3t in developing the market for p ivate infrastructure finance in EMDEs: both on the demand d 0, in the numbers of structurally s und and bankable projects seeking finance, and gradual em 1 nce of EMDE infrastructure as a recognized asset class; and the supply side, in the range c : jate investors that actively participate in financing those projects. Achieving these goals wil :i iefit from collective action betwe en this range of entities-to leverage resources and know e3:1; a to find solutions to complex nfrastructure financing challenges that no single institutic n : )uld achieve alone. (E) In support of these goals, tho Parties propose the establishment of a Global Infrastructur( :i ility Partnership Program ("GIF" . The GIF will be an open global platform aiming at leverali n; the efforts of the wide range of nstitutions currently engaged in supporting EMDE infrastruc i -E with the participation of private infrastructure investors, coalescing around project prel -n .ion, structuring, and risk mitigat on for individual infrastructure investments. In this regard, 1:11E GIF aims to complement existing and proposed services and initiatives currently supporte< b the Parties and other prospectiv: GIF partners. The GIF intends to provide resources to prep 43 vell- structured, infrastructure projects, and to serve as an additional mechanism for acces : ,i the expertise of the Parties and other GIF partners, in combination with guidance from prc ; , tive private sector financiers into project structures. The GIF thereby aims to achieve greater no age of official resources in the fice of substantial EMDE infrastructure needs-in particular cr irge and complex projects with tha potential to attract significant private capital. (F) The Parties are now intere:;ted in collaborating in developing the Global InfrastructurE 7; -ility Partnership Program, togeth ar with other partners. 2
ï»¿Execution Version Accordingly, the Parties have come to the following understanding: 1 Global Infrastructure Facilit I Partnership Program Framework 1.1 The GIF is intended to be based on the preliminary objectives and principles set oi t in Annex 1 (Preliminary GIF Fotndational Principles). The Parties acknowledge their mutual understanding that while the GIF Foundational Principles are an initial basis for their collat c on, they are of an indicative nature and will continue to be developed amongst the Parties and t! other potential partners until tie GIF is formally established. The final version of these obje: i\ s and principles will be agreed upon by the GIF Partners and be reflected in the agreement establishing the GIF. 1.2 The Parties intend to work together with any additional participants who may be collaborating on the GIF to fu ther enhance their coordination, in particular by developing tl iE IF, with a view to formally establi;hing the program by December 2014. 2 Further Collaboration 2.1 Pursuant to the foreg >ing, the Parties will use reasonable endeavors to continue t< collaborate in developing the GIF, including but not limited to: a. Nature and scope of ,ollaboration under the GIF, such as proposed categories of partnership and the roles, rights, and responsibilities associated with each categor b. Governance arrange nents of the GIF; c. Operational policies ipplicable to the GIF's operations; d. Scope of GIF activities and sources/uses of GIF funds, including approach to proj(t selection criteria and coordination with the Parties' existing facilities; and e. Any other aspects of collaboration required to finalize the design of the GIF, incluc r g sharing best practice and experience with regard to project preparation, through tl l L e of knowledge platforr is for the infrastructure sector. 2.2 During the process of finali2 ing the design of the GIF, the multilateral development banl s 1 ted in Annex 2 will be invited to participate as initial Technical Partners. Once the GIF d :!ii I is finalized, additional collaborative efforts are required to develop the operational details lo the GIF, at all times complem?nting existing efforts and facilities and building upon the rI red knowledge and experience of the Parties in this area. This includes determining the IE V, I of coordination between the Pirties and project origination process. 3 General 3.1 This Collaboration Ai rangement is not a legally binding agreement or commitmen t' he Parties to enter into or provice support for any specific activity or project. The Parties acknowledge that the provisi >ns of this Collaboration Arrangement represent their commc I understanding and intentions only and that the Parties do not intend to create or impose al1 igal obligations or liabilities on ary Party. 3.2 This Collaboration A rangement is valid and effective for a period of one year fron date thereof, unless superse Jed at an earlier date by the establishment of the GIF. 3.3 The Parties expect that this document and information with respect to the collabo ;ti. activities contemplated herei: will be publicly disclosed. Such disclosure will be made in accordance with the Parties' respective disclosure policies. The Parties plan to consult wi i E ch 3
ï»¿Execution Version other concerning the manner and form of any acknowledgment of the other Party's suppor regarding the activities. 3.4 Nothing in this arranc ement will constitute or be construed as a waiver, renunciatic r other modification of any of tf e privileges, immunities and exemptions granted to any of th Parties under their constituent documents, international conventions and any applicab e la- In witness whereof, each of the Part ies has caused this Collaboration Arrangement to be executE d il two (2) counterparts of equal content and form by a duly authorized representative of each Party a :- he date first set forth above. 4

ï»¿Execution Version THE WORLD BANK GROUP, comprising the INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTIOI V D DEVELOPMENT, the INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT ASSOCIATION, the INTERNATIONAL FINANCE CORPORATION and the M1IULTILATERAL INVESTMENT GUARANTEE AGENCY By: IM WING KIM, PRESIDEN 6
ï»¿Execution Version Annex 1 Preliriinary GIF Foundational Principles 1 Objectives 1.1 The objective of the GIF is to promote private sector investment in infrastructure p' (J .ts in emerging markets and de%eloping economies (EMDEs) through robust project preparat i provision of appropriate risk mitigation instruments, and thereby increasing the commercie :H I institutional investor engagerient in the EMDE infrastructure market. It is focused on collaboration in complex pub ic-private partnerships and projects with potential for comme .E viability which require project preparation resources, policy dialogue and eventual infrastri. c1 3 financing solutions that no single institution could achieve alone. 1.2 To this end, the GIF aims to create a global platform to provide financial and coon i u: ion resources in collaboration wi-h the project preparation, advisory, and financing efforts of tl a v de range of donor and development finance institutions currently engaged in supporting EMC infrastructure, with the input and ideas of private infrastructure investors. GIF's engageme * c uld stretch from upstream suppot on project definition, preparation, and investment feasibility assessment, through to downstream transaction preparation, financial structuring, and ris mitigation/credit enhanceme int. 1.3 Over the longer terrr, by contributing to the stock of high quality and well-structurEc infrastructure projects, the G F can be expected to help in the development of EMDE infrastructure as an asset class attractive to a wide range of private investors seeking lonc - e n assets in faster growing ecor omies, but which until now have been presented only limited infrastructure investment opr!ortunities that meet their risk tolerance and investment profil E. 2 Operating Principles 2.1 The GIF intends to cperate according to the following core principles, to be finaliz :I :on agreement among GIF partn rs: (i) Leveraging the private sector-specializing in project financing modalities t it vill draw together cc mparative advantages of public and private sectors; (ii) Addressing public goods-focusing on core infrastructure; particularly thos:! infrastructure projects that are climate friendly or trade enabling; (iii) Promoting sustainability and inclusiveness-ensuring projects adhere to :E practice standar is for social and environmental responsibility; and (iv) Collaborating, #omplementing and partnering for solutions-mobilizng t .1; ical and financial resources of all partner entities-World Bank Group entities, mL It 1 eral development institutions, other public institutions, and private investors-in ai i innovative and f exible way, to complement existing capacities, achieve great:!i leverage and address the complex infrastructure financing challenges that arl beyond the rescurces of any individual partner. 3 Institutional Arrangements and Governance 3.1 The GIF is expectec to involve a wide range of stakeholders who are involved in a development and implementation of infrastructure projects, both public and private. GIF pi) ti irs are expected to fall into one or more of the following categories: 7
ï»¿Execution Version (i) Funding Partner ;-Partners that provide financial contributions to the GIF wil bE considered Fundi ig Partners. (ii) Technical Partnurs-Partners that can and who will agree to provide specific technical advice cnd support to GIF activities including execution of GIF-funde, activities and/or provision of GIF-backed credit enhancement or liquidity sLppc t instruments. (iii) Advisory Partners-Private investors or entities that represent the voice of commercial and/cr institutional investment, whether pension funds, insurance companies, sove eign wealth funds, banks or other financial institutions, as wE 1 a other multilateral or bilateral agencies engaged in supporting private sector infrastructure pro ects, to be invited into discussions related to project preparal c n optimal approaches to financial structuring, and the design and use of risk instruments, with a view to ensure suitability of projects for commercial and/or institutional investment. 3.2 A GIF Governing Ccuncil is proposed to oversee the GIF's strategic programminj management and use of funcs, and development of operational policies and procedures; E nA hold the GIF Management Ur it (see section 4.1) accountable for delivering on the facility's objectives and principles, with advice and support from the Advisory Partners. The cornpo i ic of the Governing Council will be agreed between IBRD and prospective partners, but is propi,s e: to comprise representatives of Funding and Technical Partners. 3.3 An Advisory Counc I comprised of all GIF partners, chaired by the Managing Dirc t!o and Chief Financial Officer oi the World Bank Group, will be periodically convened to facili : le coordination of GIF activities and support GIF operations. This Advisory Council will serve a: sounding board, providing gLidance and support for GIF Management, and in particular wJ view to ensuring suitability of projects for private sector investment. 4 Management 4.1 The GIF will be adm nistered by the World Bank Group, through a small, dedicate: Ie Im established for this purpose 'the GIF Management Unit). The GIF Management Unit will ft r c:n as a coordinating body as pr)jects are identified for inclusion in the pipeline, and then mo' E toward technical support anc financing phases. The GIF Management Unit will not lead in:1 ual projects. 4.2 GIF activity implementation teams will be led by selected staff of Technical PartnEr institutions, coordinated by the GIF Management Unit in consultation with client governmE r IE according to specific project requirements and the project origination processes. Compoc it c of the implementation teams rr ay vary according to the need of individual projects and govE ri ir ents. 5 Activities and Projects 5.1 Project selection c iteria and processes could be developed to reflect the follo tv r principles: (i) Development inpact-projects that support the development goals of the C F partner institutic ns; (ii) Alignment-projects that are aligned with recipient/sponsor country prioritie. ir I strategies; (iii) Complexity-p,ojects that require multiple parties to come together to provi( E structuring, arranging and financial support, and/or projects which require a t 1r of financial instruments; and 8
ï»¿Execution Version (iv) Catalytic Impact-projects that have significant potential to achieve financial 1 a lity, leverage public funds, and attract private sector and/or institutional investors- s. 1 as through Public -Private Partnership (PPP) modalities-while still meeting government's sei vice delivery objectives. The GIF will focus on infrastructure investments that have global public good characteristics : ich as climate friendly-project, that are low emitting or encourage efficiency in the provisior (if infrastructure services; and trade enabling-projects that facilitate or enhance interconne:t v / and trade. 5.2 The scope of support provided to a particular project will be defined flexibly, with a 1w to complementing the resources and support already available from partner entities and ot '1r funding mechanisms. During :he GIF pilot phase, this support may include the following ac:i'i as, corresponding to major project development stages: (i) Project definition and enabling environment - sector planning and investment prioritization; project definition, including needs analysis and pre-feasibility scr :or 1g; and legal, regulatory, or institutional reforms; (ii) Project preparation and investment feasibility - feasibility studies, investment appraisal, and PPP structuring; (iii) Transaction support and financial structuring - preparing and implementing transactions, and design of risk mitigation/credit enhancement packages; and (iv) Financial arranging and credit enhancement - arranging and mobilizing financi - packages from a range of sources and partners. 6 Operational Policies Sound operational policies-iicluding in particular the management of environmental and :nc 3l impacts and risks, and transparency in procurement-are critical to the success of infrastri ic :t e projects in supporting sustainable, inclusive development; as well as for investors in those projects to manage financial, reputational and legal risks. In developing the appropriate framework for GIF-supported operations, the GIF could draw upon existing arrangements 0 external implementing entitie. under World Bank Partnership Programs. GIF partners will collaborate to establish an approach to fiduciary, environmental and social safeguards anc (it Br standards and policies, and cevelop, manage and oversee an accreditation process for Gl Technical Partners who are expected to function as implementing entities for GIF activities 9
